ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about the different methods and considerations that go into climate modeling, and the physical processes of climate change
I learned so much about the earth's climate system and gained insight into climate modeling

This course was a great overview of physical climate science. The first half was very foundational and provided us with a pretty good background of information about different climate systems. The second half consisted of a series of guest lectures about several different climate issues/ new technologies. I definitely learned a good amount about how our climate systems work and interact with eachother, but I think a lot of the information went over my head.
I learned about more of the physical processes in the atmosphere and the ocean that drive climate factors.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought the conceptual lectures were really interesting and I also really enjoyed having the guest lecturers visit so we could see these concepts in practice!
I think this class was well organized to facilitate student learning.

Strengths: the guest speakers were really awesome and provided a real-world perspective on the information we learned in the first half of the course. The TAs were super awesome and willing to help on the PSETs and the literature critiques. Workload wasn't terrible but I wish there was a review session before the midterm. 

Weaknesses: it felt like this course is aimed more towards graduate students. A lot of the information was super detailed and felt too high-level for me to really understand.

Strengths: The professors care about the subject and students, and lectures are both easygoing and engaging.  We also had a large number of guest lectures, which were almost all cool and informative.  The amount of work is also just right to learn things without anything that feels like busy work; I especially appreciated that we did paper reviews the 2nd half of the term, it was a great way to understand current research in a basic way and tie it to class concepts.  Weaknesses: Not much! Since we did spend the last few weeks on recent models and they were all guest lectures, it would have been nice to spend a little more time in class reviewing them or talking about CMIP generally for context.
The p-set problems were sometimes unclear or required a lot of background research. The lectures were usually interesting and it was helpful when we had discussions about real world issues.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the class did a good job of adapting, and they were flexible and considerate for varying student situations during a crazy time
Office hours could have been longer or more frequent. It was difficult to have a pset posted on wednesday and have it due monday when there was only one office hour in between.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would! it's a good overview of the concepts behind climate change and the process of climate modeling
Yes, I think that science and non-science majors would benefit from learning this material

Absolutely the first half of the class is focused on the science behind climate change, the second on the science of impacts and modeling climate change. Both halves are chock-full of interesting and critical information. It's really accessible as a science credit and you're guaranteed to learn a lot.

Yes, absolutely! It is a great foundation in climate change, and you don't need more than a basic background in physics/chemistry to understand the concepts.  Would recommend for anybody studying environmental/climate policy, or who is starting out in earth sciences or env. studies.
If you are really into the atmospheric side of climate change or the climate modeling process then yes, but there are probably other more interesting science classes.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live virtual lecture but recorded for anyone who had a conflict with the time.
live lectures were recorded, live virtual office hours
